{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3549084,"name":"Mikiyas Asmamaw","username":"MikiA30","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/59ef9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T06:36:09.824Z","cooked":"

Hello, we have a rookie team here wanting to implement climbing. We just got done with our first ever regionals and we ended up getting the rookie all star award and played very good defense and after some struggle with our robot we had it finally work properly to score on the first 3 levels. For the our next FRC competition next week, we wanted to implement climbing. We have ideas about doing a deep hang but we might end up shallow hanging. We have some ideas with gear boxes, (I think we have a 12:1 but we can make a custom one if a higher ratio is needed). We aren’t sure if we should use one or two motors?? Does anyone have ideas on if a single motor will hold up a robot close to 115 pounds? We have many motor options! We have NEOs, Kraken X60s, and CIM motors. I’m sure some of my questions are dumb but we are literally a brand new team with no experience. We’ve managed to get a neat elevator and drive train but we want to push our limits more. Maybe if I have time I’ll play around with limelights for Apriltag usage but right now climbing is the priority!! so If you could give tips on gear boxes and which type of motor (and how many) to use that would be great. If you have a robot that hangs feel free to give tips or let us know how you went about gear boxes and motors. Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T06:36:09.824Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":53,"reads":409,"readers_count":408,"score":336.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"Mikiyas Asmamaw","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73552,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549086,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T06:40:39.515Z","cooked":"

I would use only one motor. Modern FRC brushless motors are ridiculously overpowered and will climb plenty fast such that something other than motor power will limit your climb speed (most likely the strength of your climber or inertia being annoying). You can get any torque you want with enough gearing.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T06:40:39.515Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":384,"readers_count":383,"score":176.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549092,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T06:46:37.795Z","cooked":"

Even with a CIM, you only need one motor. This year’s climb only requires that the robot get off the ground, so the power required is low.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T06:46:37.795Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":362,"readers_count":361,"score":117.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/3","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549104,"name":"","username":"Kully","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kully/{size}/264955_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T07:14:38.127Z","cooked":"

One motor should be enough. kraken will be best as it is the strongest but neo can also be just fine if you don’t have enough krakens

Also you would need a higher ratio than 12:1
75:1 should be enough(probably even more than enough)

!NOTICE the ratio depends on the mechanism 75:1 is an arbitrary numer that should work for most traditional climbers but some climbers might need an even higher ratio.

Also dont forget to set current limits in code to make sure you dont burn the motor

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T07:15:05.714Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":335,"readers_count":334,"score":76.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54481,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor of ftc 12016, 21850"},"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549145,"name":"Primo 4586","username":"Primo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/primo/{size}/253910_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T11:19:26.383Z","cooked":"

a good strategy is to calculate exactly how much power you want over speed.
there is a lot of online calculators that you can use.

Our team is using one Kraken X60. It’s easier to program than neos, and has more torque than X44s. We are also attaching planetary gearbox to increase gear ratio and torque.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T12:38:41.612Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":59.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"Hadi Al Sati","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62772,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"334 drive coach and strategy lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549200,"name":"Ben Zislin","username":"Mechaman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mechaman/{size}/266877_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T12:53:59.239Z","cooked":"

An important distinction to make here is how the mechanism is being driven. 12:1 on a pivot is so fast It couldn’t lift 10 lbs, but 12:1 on a small spool winching on something is a lot more. I would consider the mechanism as a whole, access forces, and work back from there.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T12:53:59.239Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":202,"readers_count":201,"score":70.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"Ben Zislin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61430,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRCtees"},"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549241,"name":"Scott McRoberts","username":"Connector5086","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/3ec8ea/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T13:46:05.729Z","cooked":"

The length of your mechanisms arm will determine the gear ratio needed. A spool diameter of 2” is considered a 1” arm so a low gear ratio is required. A longer arm say 10” would require a higher gear ratio in the 300 to1 or higher range. Picking the right gear ratio to balance between speed and power can be easier if you use the jvn calculator Paper: JVN's Mechanical Design Calculator 2016
I like to use a high enough ratio that the motor won’t back drive in brake mode after teleop has ended. Some teams use a ratcheting mechanism to prevent back driving.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T13:46:05.729Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":32.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"Scott McRoberts","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/paper-jvns-mechanical-design-calculator-2016/146281","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Paper: JVN's Mechanical Design Calculator 2016","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57655,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549367,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T15:45:50.667Z","cooked":"

As a rookie team, you are facing a long and steep learning curve. Copying a proven design and learning about how and why it works will shorten your learning curve. Thus, I would highly recommend you consider adapting the Everybot climber design. There is documentation with detailed instructions for how to make it. The documentation also describes why it works and how to adapt it to other robots. If you are near other teams with a CNC router, they can use the publicly available CAD to make the parts for you. Otherwise, you can purchase them from AndyMark.com. There is even a discord channel (and the Chief Delphi) thread where you can ask questions and the group that developed the Everybot will answer them.

When I was doing the weighing of virtually all the robots at the Tomball competition this past weekend, I noticed that roughly half of the teams used the Everybot climber or was obviously inspired by it. This included quite a few teams with the experience and resources to design and build something totally different, from scratch, yet they chose to use the Everybot design.

The 2025 Robonauts FRC Everybot Low Resource Build General Forum
The 2025 Robonauts Everybot The Robonauts FRC Everybot is an affordable, competitive, and elegant robot that can be built with only common tools, a basic 3D printer, items purchased from your local hardware store, and online from various FRC retailers with a budget of approximately $1500 in addition to what comes in the FIRST Kit of Parts. The mission of FRC Everybot is to provide a comprehensive set of build resources to field a competitive and affordable robot intended to play the FIRST Robot…

You should only really need 1 motor to climb. However, your gear ratio is what is going to determine that. And remember - you’ll need a way to stay up there once you make it.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T15:53:36.481Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":18.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":494465,"topic_slug":"how-many-motors-for-hang","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/how-many-motors-for-hang/494465/10","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549380,"name":"Chris_Elston","username":"Chris_Elston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_elston/{size}/256883_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T16:04:46.976Z","cooked":"

We climb with a strap directly under the chain. This gives the gearbox the maximum amount of leverage to just pull straight down with no mechanical disadvantage.

Our winch spool is 2" with a MaxPlantary is two 9:1 ratios which gives us 81:1 with a Kraken X60. We are actually gunna try this with an X44 later, we think we can do it. It’s not enough ratio to hold it up, so we have a ratchet system to click it up and lock it up so the motor doesn’t have to stall the whole weight once up in the air.

Earlier in the season we had Kraken X60 and QTY (3) 5:1 which gave us 125:1 and we did not need a ratchet system. It held in the air no problems. Hope that helps. There is gopro footage in our release video that shows how the strap and winch work.

Hope that helps.
